item.title: That New Silent Hill 2 Movie Has A Horrific 7% On Rotten Tomatoes
item.content:encoded:
Return to Silent Hill, a live-action film adaptation of Konamiâ€™s beloved Silent Hill 2, hits theaters later this week. Early reviews for the horror flick are as scary as any monster from the games.

First announced in 2022, Return to Silent Hill releases on January 23. It isnâ€™t connected to the past two Silent Hill movies, even though it was directed by the first filmâ€™s Christophe Gans, and is instead a loose adaptation of the PS2-era survival horror classic Silent Hill 2. Marketing for this film has been minimal to say the least, partially because it seems the executives involved realized it wasnâ€™t great back when it wrapped filming in 2023, and the movie is only seeing the light of day after that recent Silent Hill 2 remake did so well. But after the delay and the lack of marketing, perhaps this is a very good horror film? Nope. Doesnâ€™t seem like it.

As of January 21, there are 15 reviews for Return to Silent Hill on critic aggregator Rotten Tomatoes. And the new movie has an abysmal seven percent Tomatometer score. For those not familiar with Rotten Tomatoes, that ainâ€™t a great score. In fact, if this seven percent score holds, Return to Silent Hill will go down as one of the worst-reviewed movies ever. Yikes.

The general consensus from critics is that while parts of Return to Silent Hill look great, the film is a boring, sloppy, confusing, and (perhaps worst of all for the genre) not-very-scary movie about a main character that is hard to relate to and who seems more confused than terrified.

â€œThis powerful survival horror story has been turned into an ugly, laughable adaptation that proves that maybe we shouldâ€™ve never gone back to Silent Hill,â€ said Ross Bonaime over at Collider.

â€œChristophe Gansâ€™s film does away with all the psychosexual nuance of Silent Hill 2,â€ claims Justin Clark at Slant Magazine. 

â€œI found the experience difficult to sit through and nonsensical from moment to moment, with its confounding story and shoddy CGI matched only by its lack of entertainment value,â€ said critic Brian Eggert.

At the moment, there is only one non-rotten score, from Dominic Baez at the Seattle Times, and it doesnâ€™t read like a loving endorsement of the movie. Instead, it seems like Baez found most of the movie bad, but enjoyed the ending. The end credits are apparently very â€œstylish.â€ When critics are praising your credits and not much else, thatâ€™s a bad sign.



https://kotaku.com/return-to-silent-hill-2-movie-review-metacritic-score-rotten-tomatoes-tomatometer-2000661964

item.title: Video Game God Of War Congratulates Live Action God Of War
item.content:encoded:
Christopher Judge comments on his fellow Kratos. A new Kickstarter will transform your Switch 2 dock into an old-school GameCube. And two people who worked on Pirates of the Caribbean argue about whatâ€™s to blame for modern VFX looking dull and lifeless. Itâ€™s a very late edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotakuâ€˜s daily roundup of gaming news, rumors, and culture.

Whoâ€™s ready for more bad news for PC gaming? Samsung and SK Hynix are reportedly dropping NAND production to focus on DRAM. That could mean even more expensive SSDs. Bad timing for me to replace the PC I built back in 2015 with an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960.

Christopher Judge has weighed in on Ryan Hurst being Kratos in the Prime TV series

Christopher Judge reacts to Ryan Hurst being cast as Kratos in the live-action 'God of War' show ğŸª“

â€œItâ€™s a magnificent choice. Great actor and a gamer who actually played God of War since its inception. So Kudos, youâ€™ve got a great live-action Kratos" pic.twitter.com/XFvPaMftH3

â€” Culture Crave ğŸ¿ (@CultureCrave) January 21, 2026

â€œItâ€™s a magnificent choice,â€ the in-game performer for the titular character said this week. â€œGreat actor and a gamer who actually played God of War since its inception. So kudos, youâ€™ve got a great live-action Kratos.â€ The TV series also revealed that Max Parker will play the Watchman of Asgard, Heimdall.

Chris Pratt promises the Mario Galaxy movie still has more characters to reveal

â€œIâ€™m not allowed to say what they are, but yes, there are some really incredibleâ€¦Well, I think some of them have been released in the trailerâ€“Rosalina, Bowser Jr.â€“and then thereâ€™s even a couple more that are not in the trailer that people should be excited to see,â€ the star of Mercy told Gamesradar. Who could it be?

The maker of Payday 3 is laying off developers

Multiple staffers at Starbreeze Studios have been let go, Insider Gaming reports. â€œToday, many of us at Starbreeze, Stockholm, got sad news and Iâ€™m now seeking a new role and would appreciate your support,â€ wrote one of them on LinkedIn. â€œAfter over 7 years, the longest Iâ€™ve ever been at any company in any industry, my time has (more than likely) come.â€

No online multiplayer for Lego Batman: Legacy of the Dark Knight

Following in the footsteps of all the previous Lego games, the new Lego Batman wonâ€™t have online co-op. â€œFans of all generations will be able to enjoy the game solo or team up with a friend or family member through two-player local couch cooperative gameplay only,â€ reads the FAQ (via Prima Games).

Turn your Switch 2 into a GameCube

Battle Dock coming soon! pic.twitter.com/hRdu7zI6IV

â€” Retro Fighters (@retrofightersco) January 19, 2026

A new dock on Kickstarter promises to do exactly that. Itâ€™s going for $40 with a January ship date and attaches directly to your existing Switch 2 dock. It comes in various old-school GameCube colors like silver, indigo, and orange, and has connectors for up to four of the retro consoleâ€™s controllers. Perfect for when Switch Online adds Mario Kart Double Dash and Smash Bros. Melee, if ever.

Yakuza Kiwami 3 & Dark Ties gets a free demo

Itâ€™s out today on PC and console, including Switch 2, and lets players experience a bit of the Ryukyu district in Okinawa as Kiryu and the seriesâ€™ familiar Kamurocho setting in Tokyo as Mine. The full remaster and all-new side story releases on all platforms on February 12.

Dueling Pirates of the Caribbean VFX takes

Director Gore Verbinksi talked to But Why Tho (via VGC) about the state of VFX. â€œSo it used to be a divide, with Unreal Engine being very good at video games, but then people started thinking maybe movies can also use Unreal for finished visual effects,â€ he said. â€œSo you have this sort of gaming aesthetic entering the world of cinema.â€ He added, â€œI think that Unreal Engine coming in and replacing Maya as a sort of fundamental is the greatest slip backwards.â€

Epic Games VFX supervisor Pat Tubach, who said he also worked on the Pirates movies, fired back. â€œItâ€™s inaccurate for anyone in the industry to claim that one tool is to blame for some erroneously perceived issues with the state of VFX and CGI,â€ Tubach said in a statement to VGC. â€œUnreal Engine is primarily used for pre-visualization, virtual production, and in some cases final pixels. I can guarantee that the artists working on big blockbuster VFX films like Pirates of the Caribbean 10-15 years ago could only dream about having a tool as powerful as Unreal Engine on their desks to help them get the job done. And I should knowâ€“I was one of them.â€

ICYMI:

  • Stop doomscrolling and go play Forza Horizon 5
  • One analysis firm predicts the Switch 2 is about to go up in price
  • The new Life Is Strange is coming sooner than expected with some unexpected story choices

Watch this:
